title: Lesson 1: The Law of Conservation of Mass
content:
Lesson 1: The Law of Conservation of Mass

The Universe's Ultimate Rule: Nothing is Ever Truly Lost!

Have you ever watched a campfire and wondered... where does all the wood go?

A big, heavy log burns for hours, and all that's left is a tiny, light pile of ash. It feels like the wood just vanished into thin air! This puzzle baffled people for thousands of years. But what if I told you that nothing was actually lost? Let's uncover the secret behind this amazing "disappearing" act.

First, What Happens in a Reaction?

In science, when substances mix and change to create completely new substances, we call it a chemical reaction. The ingredients you start with are called reactants, and the new stuff you end up with is called products.

Starting stuff

â†’

Ending stuff

The Golden Rule: The Law of Conservation of Mass

A brilliant scientist named Antoine Lavoisier discovered the answer to the burning log mystery. After many careful experiments, he stated the law:

"Mass can neither be created nor destroyed in a chemical reaction."

This simply means that the total mass of the reactants before a reaction is ALWAYS EQUAL to the total mass of the products after the reaction. Nothing disappears! The "stuff" just changes form.

Let's See it in Action: The Sealed Flask Experiment

This is like the experiment in your textbook (Activity 3.1). It proves the law perfectly. Let's imagine doing it step-by-step.

Step 1: Set Up and Weigh

We take a flask containing one chemical (Solution Y) and hang a small tube with another chemical (Solution X) inside it. We seal the flask with a cork so nothing can get in or out. Then, we place it on a scale and record the total mass.

Step 2: Mix and Observe

Now, we tilt the flask to mix Solution X and Solution Y. A chemical reaction occurs! We might see a new solid form (a precipitate) or the color change. It looks completely different inside.

Step 3: Weigh Again - The Magic!

After the reaction is complete, we place the sealed flask back on the scale. And here's the crucial part: the mass is EXACTLY THE SAME! Even though the substances inside changed, the total mass did not.

Why was the cork so important?

The cork creates a closed system. This solves the burning log mystery! When a log burns in the open, smoke and gases (which have mass!) escape into the air. In our flask, if any gas was made, the cork trapped it, so its mass was still counted. The law holds true, you just have to make sure you weigh *everything*!

Lesson Summary

What goes in, must come out (in some form)!

Mass is Conserved!
questions:
Lesson 1: Check Your Understanding

Q. 1 In your own words, what is the most important rule of the Law of Conservation of Mass?

Answer:

The main rule is that in any chemical reaction, you can't create new matter or destroy the matter that's already there. The total amount of "stuff" (mass) you start with is the exact same amount you end up with. It just gets rearranged into new substances.

Q. 2 If you burn a 2 kg log of wood in a sealed, fireproof container that also contains 0.5 kg of oxygen, what will be the total mass of the container's contents (ash, smoke, gases) after the log has completely burned?

Answer:

Step 1: Identify the Reactants.
The reactants are the things that react. In this case, it's the log of wood and the oxygen gas.

Step 2: Find the Total Mass of Reactants.
We just need to add the masses of the reactants together.
Mass of log = 2 kg
Mass of oxygen = 0.5 kg
Total Reactant Mass = 2 kg + 0.5 kg = 2.5 kg

Step 3: Apply the Law of Conservation of Mass.
The law states: Total Mass of Reactants = Total Mass of Products.
Since the container is sealed, nothing can escape. So, the total mass inside must stay the same.

The total mass of the contents after burning will be 2.5 kg.

Q. 3 In a reaction, 10 grams of calcium carbonate powder is heated. It breaks down to form 5.6 grams of calcium oxide and some carbon dioxide gas. How many grams of carbon dioxide gas were produced?

Answer:

Step 1: Identify the Reactant and Products.
Reactant: Calcium carbonate (10 g)
Products: Calcium oxide (5.6 g) and Carbon dioxide gas (? g)

Step 2: Write down the equation based on the Law of Conservation of Mass.
Mass of Reactant = (Mass of Product 1) + (Mass of Product 2)
10 g = 5.6 g + (Mass of carbon dioxide)

Step 3: Solve for the unknown mass.
To find the mass of the carbon dioxide, we rearrange the equation:
Mass of carbon dioxide = 10 g - 5.6 g

4.4 grams of carbon dioxide gas were produced.

Q. 4 Why is it important to put a cork on the flask in an experiment designed to prove the Law of Conservation of Mass, especially if a gas might be produced?

Answer:

The cork is crucial because it creates a closed system. This means nothing can get in and, more importantly, nothing can get out.

If a gas is produced during the reaction, it has mass. In an open flask, this gas would escape into the room, and the flask would seem to lose mass. This would make it look like the law was broken. By sealing the flask with a cork, we trap the gas, ensuring its mass is included in the final measurement. This proves that the total mass really does stay the same.

Q. 5 A student performs a reaction by mixing 50 g of Solution A and 50 g of Solution B in an open beaker. After the reaction, she finds the total mass is only 98 g. Did she break the Law of Conservation of Mass? Explain what likely happened.

Answer:

No, she did not break the law! The Law of Conservation of Mass is always true.

Hereâ€™s what likely happened:

  • The total starting mass (reactants) was 50 g + 50 g = 100 g.
  • The final measured mass was 98 g.
  • This means 100 g - 98 g = 2 g of mass is "missing".
  • Because the experiment was in an open beaker, the missing 2 g must have been a gas that was produced by the reaction and escaped into the air.

Q. 6 Identify the reactants and products in the following chemical reaction:
Hydrogen gas + Oxygen gas â†’ Water

Answer:

Reactants: These are the substances you start with, on the left side of the arrow. The reactants are Hydrogen gas and Oxygen gas.

Product: This is the new substance that is formed, on the right side of the arrow. The product is Water.

Q. 7 If 4 g of hydrogen reacts completely with some oxygen to produce 36 g of water, how much oxygen must have been used in the reaction?

Answer:

Step 1: Write down the reaction in terms of mass.
Mass of Hydrogen + Mass of Oxygen = Mass of Water

Step 2: Fill in the values you know.
4 g + (Mass of Oxygen) = 36 g

Step 3: Solve for the unknown mass of oxygen.
Mass of Oxygen = 36 g - 4 g

32 grams of oxygen must have been used.

Q. 8 Which scientist is credited with establishing the Law of Conservation of Mass?

Antoine Lavoisier, an 18th-century French chemist.

Q. 9 True or False: The Law of Conservation of Mass means that the number of atoms of each element must be the same before and after a reaction.

Answer: True!

This is a great way to think about it! Since atoms have mass, and mass cannot be created or destroyed, the atoms themselves are just rearranged during a reaction, not lost or gained. This idea is a key part of why the law works.

Q. 10 In a reaction from your textbook, 5.3 g of sodium carbonate reacted with 6.0 g of acetic acid. The products were 2.2 g of carbon dioxide, 0.9 g of water, and some sodium acetate. Show that this observation agrees with the law of conservation of mass by calculating the mass of sodium acetate formed.

Answer:

Step 1: Calculate the total mass of the reactants.
Reactants: sodium carbonate and acetic acid
Total Reactant Mass = 5.3 g + 6.0 g = 11.3 g

Step 2: Write the equation for the products.
Products: carbon dioxide, water, and sodium acetate
Total Product Mass = 2.2 g + 0.9 g + (Mass of sodium acetate)

Step 3: Apply the Law of Conservation of Mass.
Total Mass of Reactants = Total Mass of Products
11.3 g = 2.2 g + 0.9 g + (Mass of sodium acetate)
11.3 g = 3.1 g + (Mass of sodium acetate)

Step 4: Solve for the mass of sodium acetate.
Mass of sodium acetate = 11.3 g - 3.1 g

The mass of sodium acetate formed is 8.2 g. This shows the observation is in perfect agreement with the law!
exercises:
Lesson 1: Practice Exercises

1 Complete the statement of the Law of Conservation of Mass: "Mass can neither be _________ nor _________ in a chemical reaction."

Answer: created, destroyed

2 The scale below is perfectly balanced. What is the missing mass of Product B?

Answer:

1. The total mass of reactants is 25 g.

2. According to the law, the total mass of products must also be 25 g.

3. Mass of Product A + Mass of Product B = 25 g.

4. 15 g + ? g = 25 g.

5. The missing mass is 25 g - 15 g = 10 g.

3 In the reaction shown, which number points to the Reactants and which points to the Products?

Answer:

1 points to the Reactants (the starting materials).
2 points to the Products (the new substances formed).

4 A student writes in their notebook: "I mixed 12 g of chemical X with 8 g of chemical Y. The reaction produced 22 g of chemical Z. This proves mass can be created!" What is wrong with their conclusion?

Answer:

The student made an error in their measurement, not in the law of physics! Mass cannot be created.
Correct calculation: 12 g (X) + 8 g (Y) = 20 g.
The student should have measured exactly 20 g of product Z. The extra 2 g in their final measurement likely came from an error, such as not zeroing the scale correctly or a contaminated sample.

5 Which setup, A or B, is appropriate for testing the Law of Conservation of Mass? Why?

Answer:

Setup B (Closed) is the correct choice.
Why: In Setup A, if the reaction produces a gas, it will escape into the air, and the final mass will appear lower. Setup B is a closed system that traps everything, ensuring that the mass of any gas produced is included in the final measurement. This allows for a fair test of the law.

6A flashbulb contains magnesium and oxygen. Before use, it weighs 2.0 g. After the flash, it still weighs 2.0 g. What does this tell you about the reaction?

Answer:

This shows that the flashbulb is a closed system. The reaction between magnesium and oxygen happens inside the sealed bulb, and even though a new substance (magnesium oxide) is formed, the total mass remains constant, perfectly demonstrating the Law of Conservation of Mass.

7If 20 g of reactant A breaks down into 12 g of product B and an unknown amount of product C, what is the mass of product C?

Answer:

Total reactant mass is 20 g. Total product mass must also be 20 g. So, Mass of C = 20 g - 12 g = 8 g.

8True or False: When an ice cube (solid water) melts into liquid water, its mass decreases. Explain your answer.

Answer:

False. Melting is a physical change, not a chemical reaction, but the law of conservation of mass still applies. The mass of the liquid water will be exactly the same as the mass of the ice cube. Nothing is lost, the particles just changed their arrangement.

9The growing plant puzzle: A tiny 1 g seed grows into a huge 500 kg tree. This seems to create mass from nothing. How does the Law of Conservation of Mass explain where the extra 499.999 kg came from?

Answer:

The tree is not creating mass! It's an open system that is constantly taking in reactants from its environment. It gets its mass from:
1. Carbon dioxide from the air.
2. Water from the soil.
3. Nutrients and minerals from the soil.
The tree's final mass is the sum of the mass of the seed plus all the mass it took in during its life.

10In the reaction to make salt, 2.3 g of sodium and 3.5 g of chlorine combine. What will be the mass of the sodium chloride (salt) produced?

Answer:

Mass of product = Mass of sodium + Mass of chlorine = 2.3 g + 3.5 g = 5.8 g.

11A reaction produces a gas. To prove the Law of Conservation of Mass, should you perform the experiment in a beaker or a sealed syringe?

Answer:

A sealed syringe. A beaker is an open system and the gas would escape, leading to an apparent loss of mass.

12If you bake a cake, the final cake usually weighs less than the batter you put in the oven. Why doesn't this break the law of conservation of mass?

Answer:

The "lost" mass isn't destroyed. It's the mass of the water in the batter that turned into steam (a gas) and escaped from the cake into the oven. If you could capture and weigh that steam, the total mass would be conserved.

13To make 44 g of carbon dioxide, you need 12 g of carbon. How much oxygen do you need?

Answer:

Mass of Oxygen = Mass of Carbon Dioxide - Mass of Carbon = 44 g - 12 g = 32 g.

14What is the difference between a reactant and a product?

Answer:

A reactant is a substance that you start with in a chemical reaction. A product is a new substance that is formed at the end of the reaction.

15A 100 g sample of a chemical is sealed in a glass tube and heated. The chemical turns from a blue powder into a white powder and a brown gas is seen inside the tube. What is the total mass of the glass tube and its contents after heating?

Answer:

Exactly 100 g. Because the tube is sealed (a closed system), no mass can escape. Even though the chemical changed form, the total mass inside the tube remains the same.
intros:
Lesson 1: The Law of Conservation of Mass

Let's uncover one of the most fundamental rules of the universe, a rule that governs everything from baking a cake to launching a rocket! It's like a magic trick where nothing ever truly disappears.

The Baker's Secret

If you mix ingredients to bake a cake, does some of the "stuff" just disappear in the oven?

Think about baking. You start with a list of ingredients, each with its own weight. After you mix them all up and bake them, you get a delicious final product. The Law of Conservation of Mass is like the baker's secret rule: the total weight of all your ingredients before baking is the same as the total weight of your final cake (including any steam that might have escaped!). Nothing is lost, it just changes into a tastier form.

In chemistry, just like in the kitchen, you can't create or destroy ingredientsâ€”you just mix them up!

The LEGO Masterpiece

If you build a spaceship with a 1 kg box of LEGOs, how much will the spaceship weigh?

Imagine you're a master builder with a pile of LEGO blocks. You can take them apart and build anythingâ€”a car, a castle, or a robot. But no matter how you rearrange the blocks, you still have the same number and type of blocks you started with. The total weight of your creation will always be the same as the weight of the initial pile. Chemical reactions work the same way! Atoms are like LEGOs that get rearranged to form new things, but no atoms are ever lost or gained in the process.

Matter is not lost, it's just rebuilt.

The Mystery of the Burning Campfire

When a big log burns into a tiny pile of ash, where does the rest of it go?

It certainly looks like the log disappears! This puzzled people for centuries. But scientists discovered that the log doesn't just vanish. When it burns, it reacts with oxygen from the air and changes into other substances: ash, smoke, and invisible gases like carbon dioxide. If we could trap all the smoke and gases and weigh them along with the ash, we'd find their total mass is exactly the same as the original log plus the oxygen it used.

Nothing truly disappears; it just changes its disguise.

The Sealed Jar Experiment

If chemicals react inside a sealed jar, will its weight change?

This is a classic science experiment, just like the one in your textbook's Activity 3.1. Imagine we have a sealed jar with two chemicals inside, kept separate. We weigh it. Then, we shake the jar to mix them. A reaction happensâ€”maybe it fizzes, changes color, or gets warm. But because the jar is sealed, nothing can escape and nothing can get in. If we weigh it again, the weight is exactly the same! This proves that even during a dramatic chemical change, the total amount of "stuff" (mass) stays constant.

What's inside may change, but the total weight remains the same.

The Dissolving Sugar Puzzle

You stir a spoonful of sugar into water and it "disappears." Is it gone forever?

When sugar dissolves, its crystals break down into particles so tiny you can no longer see them. They haven't been destroyed! They just spread out evenly in the water. If you were to weigh the glass of water (100 g) and the spoonful of sugar (10 g) separately, their combined weight (110 g) would be exactly the same as the final weight of the sugar-water. The sugar's mass was simply added to the water's mass. This simple, everyday action demonstrates a powerful and universal law.

Just because you can't see it, doesn't mean it's not there!
summary:
Lesson 1 Summary

The Law of Conservation of Mass

Core Principle

The Law of Conservation of Mass, established by Antoine Lavoisier, states that:

"Mass can neither be created nor destroyed in a chemical reaction."

This means that for any chemical reaction in a closed system, the total mass of all the substances you start with (the reactants) will be exactly equal to the total mass of all the new substances you end up with (the products).

Experimental Verification

This law is proven by a simple experiment where reactants are weighed before and after they react inside a sealed container. The mass does not change.

Exam Focus

Definition: You must know the statement: "Mass can neither be created nor destroyed in a chemical reaction."

âœ“

Mathematical Form: The core idea is Total Mass of Reactants = Total Mass of Products.

âœ“

Application: If you are given the masses of all reactants except one, you can calculate the unknown mass if you know the total mass of the products (and vice versa).

âœ“

Condition: The law holds true for reactions in a closed system, where no matter can enter or escape. This is why the flask in the experiment is sealed with a cork.
